questions.question: Who were the first people to live in Canada?
questions.explanation: Indigenous peoples (First Nations, Inuit, and Métis) were the first people to live in Canada, arriving thousands of years before European explorers.

questions.question: When did the first European explorers reach Canada?
questions.explanation: The Vikings were the first Europeans to reach Canada, establishing a settlement in L'Anse aux Meadows in Newfoundland around 1000 CE.

questions.question: Who was the first European to map Canada's Atlantic coast?
questions.explanation: Jacques Cartier made three voyages to Canada between 1534 and 1542, exploring and mapping the Gulf of St. Lawrence and the St. Lawrence River.

questions.question: When did Canada become a country with its own constitution?
questions.explanation: The British North America Act (now known as the Constitution Act, 1867) created the Dominion of Canada on July 1, 1867.

questions.question: Which province was the first to grant women the right to vote in provincial elections?
questions.explanation: Manitoba was the first province to grant women the right to vote in provincial elections in 1916.

questions.question: What was the name of the 1982 document that gave Canada full independence?
questions.explanation: The Canada Act 1982 was passed by the British Parliament, giving Canada full control over its Constitution and ending Britain's remaining authority.

questions.question: Who was Canada's first Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: Sir John Alexander Macdonald was Canada's first Prime Minister, serving from 1867-1873 and 1878-1891.

questions.question: What was the Quiet Revolution?
options: The peaceful independence of Canada from Britain
A period of rapid change in Quebec during the 1960s
The gradual transition to bilingualism throughout Canada
questions.correctAnswer: A period of rapid change in Quebec during the 1960s
questions.explanation: The Quiet Revolution was a period of rapid change in Quebec in the 1960s that modernized the province and emphasized Quebec nationalism.

questions.question: When did the Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR) become the first railway to connect Canada from coast to coast?
questions.explanation: The Canadian Pacific Railway was completed in 1885, fulfilling a promise made to British Columbia when it joined Confederation.

questions.question: What significant event in Canadian history occurred at Vimy Ridge?
options: A major battle won by Canadians in World War I
The first meeting between Indigenous peoples and Europeans
The location where the Canadian Charter was signed
questions.correctAnswer: A major battle won by Canadians in World War I
questions.explanation: The Battle of Vimy Ridge took place in April 1917 during World War I. It was a significant victory for Canadian forces and is considered a defining moment in Canadian national identity.

questions.question: When did the War of 1812 take place?
questions.explanation: The War of 1812 lasted from June 1812 to February 1815. It was fought between the United States and Great Britain, with British North America (now Canada) being a major theater of war.

questions.question: Who was Louis Riel?
options: The first Prime Minister of Canada
A Métis leader who led resistance movements against the Canadian government
A French explorer who discovered the Great Lakes
An early British governor of Upper Canada
questions.correctAnswer: A Métis leader who led resistance movements against the Canadian government
questions.explanation: Louis Riel was a Métis leader who led resistance movements against the Canadian government to preserve Métis rights and culture. He led the Red River Resistance (1869-70) and the North-West Resistance (1885).

questions.question: What was the name of the ship that brought many of the first permanent European settlers to Nova Scotia in 1749?
questions.explanation: HMS Cornwallis brought many of the first permanent European settlers to establish Halifax in 1749 under the leadership of Colonel Edward Cornwallis.

questions.question: What major event occurred in Canada during the Great Depression?
questions.explanation: During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the On-to-Ottawa Trek was a protest movement of unemployed workers who traveled from relief camps in Western Canada to Ottawa to demand better working conditions and wages.

questions.question: Which event is commemorated on Remembrance Day (November 11)?
options: The end of the War of 1812
The end of World War I
The adoption of the Canadian flag
questions.correctAnswer: The end of World War I
questions.explanation: Remembrance Day commemorates the armistice that ended World War I on November 11, 1918, at 11 a.m. It honors those who died in World War I and later conflicts.

questions.question: What was the Komagata Maru incident?
options: A naval battle during World War II
A ship carrying immigrants that was turned away from Canada in 1914
A treaty between Canada and Japan
questions.correctAnswer: A ship carrying immigrants that was turned away from Canada in 1914
questions.explanation: In 1914, the Komagata Maru was a ship carrying 376 passengers, primarily Sikhs from Punjab, India. The ship was denied entry to Canada due to discriminatory immigration policies, and was forced to return to India.

questions.question: In which year did Newfoundland join Confederation to become Canada's 10th province?
questions.explanation: Newfoundland was the last province to join Canada, becoming the 10th province in 1949 following a referendum.

questions.question: What was the name of the residential school system established for Indigenous children?
questions.explanation: The Indian Residential School System was established to assimilate Indigenous children into Euro-Canadian culture. These schools caused significant harm to Indigenous children, families, and communities.

questions.question: When did the last spike complete the Canadian Pacific Railway?
questions.explanation: The last spike of the Canadian Pacific Railway was driven at Craigellachie, British Columbia, on November 7, 1885, completing Canada's first transcontinental railroad.

questions.question: Which document officially recognized the rights of First Nations, Inuit, and Métis peoples in 1982?
questions.explanation: The Constitution Act, 1982 officially recognized and affirmed the Aboriginal and treaty rights of First Nations, Inuit, and Métis peoples in Section 35.

questions.question: Which explorer is credited with naming Canada?
questions.explanation: Jacques Cartier is credited with naming Canada, derived from the Huron-Iroquois word 'kanata' meaning village or settlement, which he used to refer to the area around what is now Quebec City.

questions.question: What was the name of the company that controlled much of Canada's fur trade from 1670 to the mid-19th century?
questions.explanation: The Hudson's Bay Company, established in 1670, controlled much of the fur trade in British North America for centuries and is the oldest incorporated company in North America still in operation.

questions.question: What was the Underground Railroad?
options: A network helping escaped slaves reach freedom in Canada
questions.correctAnswer: A network helping escaped slaves reach freedom in Canada
questions.explanation: The Underground Railroad was a network of secret routes and safe houses established in the United States during the early to mid-19th century to help African American slaves escape into free states and Canada.

questions.question: In what year did the United States attempt to invade Canada?
questions.explanation: In 1812, during the War of 1812, the United States attempted to invade and take over British North America (now Canada), but the invasion was repelled.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to be elected to Parliament in Canada?
questions.explanation: Agnes Macphail was the first woman elected to the House of Commons in 1921, following the extension of voting rights to women in 1918.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Royal Proclamation of 1763?
options: It established French as an official language
It recognized Indigenous land rights and established protocols for European settlement
It united Upper and Lower Canada
It declared Canada's independence from Britain
questions.correctAnswer: It recognized Indigenous land rights and established protocols for European settlement
questions.explanation: The Royal Proclamation of 1763 established British authority over former French territories in North America and recognized Aboriginal land rights. It established that land could only be ceded to the Crown, not to individuals.

questions.question: Which event is often referred to as 'Canada's Pearl Harbor'?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Hong Kong in December 1941 is sometimes called 'Canada's Pearl Harbor.' It happened at the same time as the attack on Pearl Harbor, and resulted in the deaths or capture of nearly 2,000 Canadian soldiers.

questions.question: When did Canada adopt the maple leaf flag?
questions.explanation: The current maple leaf flag was adopted in 1965, replacing the Red Ensign that had been used previously.

questions.question: Which Prime Minister established universal health care in Canada?
questions.explanation: Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson established universal health care in the 1960s, with the Medical Care Act of 1966, though Saskatchewan had introduced a provincial plan earlier under Tommy Douglas.

questions.question: What was the Halifax Explosion?
options: A military attack during World War I
A mining disaster in Nova Scotia
The collision of two ships that caused a massive explosion
questions.correctAnswer: The collision of two ships that caused a massive explosion
questions.explanation: The Halifax Explosion occurred on December 6, 1917, when two ships collided in Halifax Harbour, causing a massive explosion that killed about 2,000 people and injured 9,000 others.

questions.question: What was the name of the rebellion led by Louis Riel in 1885?
questions.explanation: The North-West Rebellion of 1885 was led by Louis Riel in what is now Saskatchewan. The Red River Rebellion was an earlier conflict in 1869-70 in Manitoba.

questions.question: Which of these provinces was the last to join Confederation?
questions.explanation: Newfoundland and Labrador was the last province to join Confederation in 1949, 82 years after the original provinces united.

questions.question: When was Nunavut officially established as a territory?
questions.explanation: Nunavut was established as a separate territory on April 1, 1999, as a result of the largest land claims agreement in Canadian history.

questions.question: Who were the 'Famous Five' in Canadian history?
options: Five women who fought for women to be recognized legally as 'persons'
Five explorers who mapped the Canadian Arctic
Five founders of the Canadian Pacific Railway
questions.correctAnswer: Five women who fought for women to be recognized legally as 'persons'
questions.explanation: The Famous Five were Emily Murphy, Nellie McClung, Louise McKinney, Henrietta Muir Edwards, and Irene Parlby, who successfully fought for women to be recognized as 'persons' under the law in the Persons Case of 1929.

questions.question: What historical agreement divided New France into two colonies in 1791?
questions.explanation: The Constitutional Act of 1791 divided the Province of Quebec into Upper Canada (Ontario) and Lower Canada (Quebec).

questions.question: Which of these groups were NOT among the early settlers of Canada?
questions.explanation: Spanish conquistadors never established significant settlements in what is now Canada. Early settlers included Loyalists from the American Revolution, Scottish Highlanders, and Irish immigrants fleeing the potato famine.

questions.question: What was the significance of the October Crisis of 1970?
options: A terrorist crisis in Quebec that led to the War Measures Act being invoked
questions.correctAnswer: A terrorist crisis in Quebec that led to the War Measures Act being invoked
questions.explanation: The October Crisis of 1970 involved the kidnapping of a British diplomat and a Quebec cabinet minister by the FLQ (Front de libération du Québec), leading Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau to invoke the War Measures Act.

questions.question: The United Empire Loyalists were people who:
options: Remained loyal to the British Crown during the American Revolution
Fought against British rule in Canada
Were the original French settlers of Quebec
questions.correctAnswer: Remained loyal to the British Crown during the American Revolution
questions.explanation: The United Empire Loyalists were American colonists who remained loyal to the British Crown during and after the American Revolution, with many moving to what is now Canada.

questions.question: What was the name of the 1969 policy paper that proposed eliminating special status for Indigenous peoples?
questions.explanation: The 1969 White Paper proposed abolishing the Indian Act and eliminating the special legal status of Indigenous peoples. It was strongly opposed by Indigenous organizations and was later withdrawn.

questions.question: Who was Canada's first female Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: Kim Campbell became Canada's first female Prime Minister in June 1993, though her term lasted only until November of the same year.
